title: North Korea, Donald Trump, Catalonia: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
byline: By MAYA SALAM, LOUIS LUCERO II and LANCE BOOTH

title: Trump Unworried About What Former Aides Will Tell Mueller, Lawyer Says
abstract: The lawyer, Ty Cobb, said on “The New Washington” podcast that the White House staff is cooperating with an eye toward a swift end to the investigation.
multimedia.caption: Ty Cobb, the White House lawyer handling the response to the Russia investigation, said President Trump has instructed all White House staff members to cooperate with Robert S. Mueller III’s team of investigators.

title: Limit on 401(k) Savings? It’s About Paying for Tax Cuts
abstract: “This is not a retirement security story,” a tax expert says. It’s about finding revenue to pay for reductions in business taxes sooner rather than later.
multimedia.caption: Three out of four Americans say they worry about having enough money to get through retirement, and 45 percent have not saved anything for it.

title: North Korea Rouses Neighbors to Reconsider Nuclear Weapons
abstract: A debate is raging in both Japan and South Korea about the nuclear option, driven by the North’s rapidly advancing capabilities and concern the United States might hesitate to defend its allies.
byline: By DAVID E. SANGER, CHOE SANG-HUN and MOTOKO RICH
multimedia.caption: Two of South Korea’s 24 nuclear reactors. The country has a huge stockpile of spent fuel from which it can extract plutonium — enough for more than 4,300 bombs, according to a report.

title: Five Years After Sandy, Are We Better Prepared?
abstract: While much of New York City’s battered infrastructure has been repaired and even improved, most long-term resiliency measures are still years away
byline: By PATRICK McGEEHAN and WINNIE HU
multimedia.caption: Hurricane Sandy, which made landfall in the New York City region on Oct. 29, 2012, plunged Manhattan, from Midtown south to the Financial District, into darkness for several days. While much of the region’s inundated infrastructure has been repaired, many of the plans to stormproof the city are still just that — plans.
multimedia.caption.1: Hurricane Sandy, which made landfall in the New York City region on Oct. 29, 2012, plunged Manhattan, from Midtown south to the Financial District, into darkness for several days. While much of the region’s inundated infrastructure has been repaired, many of the plans to stormproof the city are still just that — plans.

title: A Student Loan Nightmare: The Teacher in the Wrong Payment Plan
abstract: After $70,000 in payments, one teacher found that he wasn’t in the public service loan forgiveness program after all. Now, he has to start over.

title: Five Years After Sandy, Are We Better Prepared?

multimedia.caption: Hurricane Sandy, which made landfall in the New York City region on Oct. 29, 2012, plunged Manhattan, from Midtown south to the Financial District, into darkness for several days. While much of the region’s inundated infrastructure has been repaired, many of the plans to stormproof the city are still just that — plans.

title: Albert Einstein’s ‘Theory of Happiness’ Fetches $1.56 Million

abstract: Head injuries account for three-fourths of the nearly 700-plus bicycle deaths that occur each year.

title: Pediatricians’ New Germ-Control Advice: Bring Your Own Toys
abstract: The American Academy of Pediatrics has a new policy on how to minimize passing germs around the doctor’s office.

title: Cody Bellinger Breaks Through, Leading the Dodgers Past the Astros
abstract: Bellinger, a rookie, had struggled through the first three games of the World Series with no hits in 13 at-bats, but his two doubles made all the difference in Game 4.
multimedia.caption: The rookie Cody Bellinger after hitting a double and driving in the run that put the Dodgers ahead in the ninth inning of their Game 4 victory in the World Series. Bellinger also doubled in the seventh inning and scored the tying run.

title: The Astros’ Alex Bregman Keeps Working at Hitting, Fielding and Spanish
abstract: Houston’s 23-year-old third baseman is intent on creating a tighter bond with his Latino teammates and particularly his three fellow infielders.
multimedia.caption: Alex Bregman, third from left, with his teammates Jose Altuve, Carlos Correa and Marwin Gonzalez. Bregman is able to move seamlessly between the Astros’ contingents of Latino and American players because he has a working knowledge of Spanish and a desire to get better at it.

title: Stranger Than Fiction: The Best True-Crime Stories
abstract: From Hollywood’s Black Dahlia case to killing sprees in 1950s London and 19th-century Paris, new books probe the grisly worst of human nature.

abstract: Six spooky fall thrillers, whose plots range from a campus crime to an international spy hunt to a young girl’s mystical self-murdering, all unsettle the neat distinctions between “hero,” “villain,” and even the reader.

title: Weinstein Sues Weinstein Company, Demanding Access to Records
abstract: Harvey Weinstein sued the studio he had co-founded, saying he needs access to records and emails to defend himself against accusations of misconduct against women.

title: Wines Are No Longer Free to Travel Across State Lines
abstract: Buying wine from a retailer out of state used to be easy, but a recent crackdown on interstate shipping is leaving wine lovers with fewer options.

abstract: General Motors says it will add at least 20 electric vehicles to its lineup by 2023. Ford followed with its own initiative with 13 offerings.
byline: By BILL VLASIC and NEAL E. BOUDETTE
multimedia.caption: Mary Barra, G.M.’s chief executive, discussing features on the battery-powered Chevrolet Bolt in January 2016. G.M. said it would introduce two new all-electric models within 18 months as part of a broader goal to create an emissions-free fleet.

title: Storm Has Car Dealers Doing Swift Business, if They Can Open

title: Apps to Provide Peace of Mind With a Teenager Behind the Wheel
abstract: Keeping tabs on a young new driver is easier than it used to be, thanks to several new apps and services intended for nervous parents.
multimedia.caption: The Life360 Driver Protect app, one of several subscription services that track drivers, guides a new user through setting up a “circle” for family members to see one another on a map. Once configured, the app collects GPS and other data from the driver’s phone to show location, route and other information.

title: Isabella L. Karle Dies at 95; Findings on Molecules Helped Husband Win Nobel
abstract: Her husband was disappointed that her work, which aided in the development of drugs for illnesses, was not cited by the Nobel committee.
multimedia.caption: Dr. Isabella L. Karle in an undated photograph. Her work helped give pharmaceutical researchers a better idea of the chemistry going on inside the body in their efforts to make drugs to treat illnesses.

title: Tom Mathews, Promoter of Liberal Causes and Candidates, Dies at 96
abstract: A former journalist, Mr. Mathews raised the profile of groups like the Peace Corps and was the spokesman for Robert F. Kennedy’s presidential campaign in 1968.

title: Paul Weitz, Astronaut on Skylab and Challenger, Dies at 85
abstract: Captain Weitz commanded the shuttle Challenger on its maiden voyage, and after it later exploded, he was among NASA officials who examined why.

title: Fats Domino Songs: Listen to 12 Essential Tracks
abstract: His easygoing image concealed the boldness and subtlety of his music — Domino was an innovator who didn’t flaunt it. A dozen songs from his prime years prove it.
multimedia.caption: Fats Domino sang songs about heartbreak and betrayal with such sly humor, they sounded like a good time.

title: Dennis Wayne, 72, Charismatic Dancer With Leading Troupes, Is Dead

title: Marina Sturdza, Romanian Princess and Humanitarian, Dies at 73
